You got something without a toy in it?
A pair of expressive pantomime "A Little Grass Shack".

Mrs. Trout is on stage, introducing hula contestants.  Gr judges the Hawaiian dancing.  The party is at full tilt - little wild, a little goofy.  Some guests (Bob, Cindy, Co and Ted) do the limbo.  Walter, Mrs. Pressman doesn't tur she hears him.
Aloha.  That's a very fetching headdress you're wearing. Ike leans into Maggie, enjoying the smell of her hair.  S notices, but acts casual.
Where did you disappear to?
Missed me bad, huh?
All the guests start banding their pineapple cups.  Walte unsteadily, lifting his pineapple.
Attention.  Listen to Walter.  Listen close, he slurs. (then) Shut up, wahines!
In the tradition that has grown through the years, it is now Toast Time!  First up, our host, "A Honey of a Beekeeper", Lou Trout.. Lou Trout stands with his glass raised.
May the groom's heart be filled with hopes and the bride's feet be filled with lead! There are shouts of "Hear hear!"  Walter roars.
May the pitter-patter of little feet not be Maggie's.
May the gifts be returned!
May the back of the dress be as pretty as the front! The laughter swells and swells, led by Walter.
Ike watches as Maggie takes the heat, raising her glass a with the others.  Bob raises his glass like the good spor Ike can't believe it.

You know the old saying, "You're not losing a daughter..."  Well, I'd like to! Walter gets a bit laugh.  He goes again. WALTER (cont'd) Maggie may not be Hale's longest running joke... (under her breath) Maggie finishes the punchline along with his father.

-- But she's certainly the fastest. Uproarious laughter.  Maggie looks terribly pained.  Ike' enough.  He pushes himself to his feet.  Walter is thrill shushes the CROWD. WALTER (cont'd) Oh, look, Mr. Graham, how about a toast?
I don't know, give me a minute. (to Maggie) Are you all right with this?
Excuse me?
Are you all right with this?  You think this is funny?
Yes.
I don't and I don't think you should...
It's a joke.  They're kidding.
(yell) Come on and give us a toast.

You want me to make a toast?  Okay... I'll give you a toast.  To Maggie's family and friends.  May you find yourselves the bull's eye of an easy target.  May you be publicly flogged for all of your bad choices and may your noses to rubbed in all of your mistakes... Ike watches their reaction.  The silence is deafening.  A guests stare at Maggie.  Mortified, she holds back tears.

That was funny. (a pause) But enough toasts, let's hula.  Let's start the music up. She gets everyone up to hula.  Band plays fast tune.  Mag walks through the CROWD down the steps and outside.  Ike follows, but Peggy grabs a coat for her.  Bob watches her Cory approaches.
Hey, Bob.  I got twenty dollars bet on--
Not now. Bob rushes after Maggie.
(calling after her) Maggie.  Maggie. (to Ike,  handing him a jacket) Here.  She may need this.  It's not really Hawaii. Ike exits.  Then, Bob comes over.
Where'd Maggie go?

Oh, she just went to get me something from the car. Cory comes over with Dennis to Bob and Peggy.  BOB/PEGGY/ DENNIS CHUFFA:  About Bart Starr and football.  (Which ke from going outside to follow Maggie).  Bob thinks about i
Ike runs after Maggie.  He grabs her arm and turns her to
I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.
You humiliated me!
No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing.  It's the theme of this party.
I had it under control.  Now they feel sorry for me.
Well, they should.  Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again. Maggie has no response. IKE (cont'd) -- Tell me something, do you really care about Mount Everest?
It's fun!  It's high.
Or the sexual habits of locusts?
That was very interesting research George was doing!
What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?
I already explained about that.
And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?
(wincing) Brian told you that?
Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.
Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.
Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.
Lost!
That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.
What!?
With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.
That's called changing your mind.
No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.
Yes I do!

No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right? He's laid her flat.  Maggie can't speak. IKE (cont'd) Am I right? She fights back angry tears.

Stop.  Stop it!  I'm getting married on Sunday, and you're just trying to make me run!  Why?  Because you're a cynical, exploitative, mean-hearted creep who wouldn't know real love if it bit him in the armpit!  And all you do is tear other people down and-and-and laugh at them, and criticize what they do, because you're too afraid to do anything yourself!  I read your column. You never wrote one about you.  I'm not the only one who's lost and you know it! Am I right?  Well?  Am I right? ANGLE ON:  Bob comes outside.

Mag.  Help me out here.  Green Bay. Right guard. Both Maggie and Ike are breathing hard.  Bob comes up to and gives Ike a very hard look as he puts his arm around fiancee. BOB (cont'd) You know... Blocked Bart Starr, crewcut ... Are you okay? Maggie adjusts her face as best she can.
Yes.
Let me take you back inside, okay? She lets him lead her away.
Jerry Kramer. Ike looks at her drooped shoulder and he shakes his head walks to his car.
Peggy and Cindy arrive for the rehearsal.  They leave Cin dog in Peggy's car and walk to the church.
Tell me, why does Maggie need another wedding rehearsal and two days before the wedding?  She's already done this.
Bob is making her visualize the ceremony.
They are in the church proper now.  Peggy waits in a pew leads Maggie and Ike up the back steps of the church.
(to Maggie) Okay, we're ready.  Want me to have Ike leave now? Maggie turns on Ike with "cheerful" hostility.
No.  No -- Actually, let's make Ike the pastor.
I'd rather not.

(sarcastically) Come on, it'll give you a great view. It's perfect. (seeing Peggy) Hey. Maggie smiles at Bob.  Ike sighs and goes with it.  Bob p to the head of the aisle and places him.  Peggy follows M into the foyer to get ready.  Cindy sits with Ted at the
Team effort, Pastor Ike... Cindy, ready? (after no response) Cindy, come on. Cindy leaves to join the girls in the foyer.
Once in the privacy of the foyer, Peggy and Maggie talk.
He's going to be the pastor?
Yep.  I want him to be front and center and to watch everything.
What happened at the luau?
(flustered) ... I don't even want to talk about the luau. (then seeing a hanging rope) What's this?
It's for the bell. Cindy joins them.
Bob's in a hurry.
Don't be nervous, Maggie.  Let us visualize.  Remember what Bob said? "Be the ball."
"Sink the putt."
"Make the shot."
"Nothing but net."
"Never say die." Maggie puts her hands up.
Go! Peggy and Cindy exit.  Maggie pulls the bell rope and swa and forth as she rings the bell.
It is Maggie's turn to enter.  They all turn expectantly. much time passes.  Ted plays the organ, then stops.  Magg swings back and forth in the foyer doorway.

Honey, are you okay? Maggie stops ringing the bell and pulls herself together. walks into the aisle looking a little shaky.  She takes a tremulous steps slowly with her eyes closed, peeking occasionally with one eye.
(taking off his jacket) At this pace, it could be an evening wedding.

Hold it!  Hold it!  I think we're taking this too fast. He begins to pace. BOB (cont'd) We need to limber you up a little. You're tensing. (thinks a moment; to Ike, moving him to groom's spot) You stand here and be me so she knows how far she'll have to go. (then to Maggie) I'm going to walk with you. Bob goes to Maggie and walks behind her. BOB (cont'd) Visualize!  Visualize!  It's game time.
Maggie walking. BOB (cont'd) You are the football.  You're spiraling through the air towards the hands of the groom. She proceeds down the aisle.  Bob behind her.
(eyes down) Yes, I'm spiraling through the air.

Maggie raises her eyes and sees Ike in front of her as gr Ike and Maggie lock gazes.  If they had to, they couldn't away.  All the things unspoken are now communicated -- th the longing. MAGGIE (cont'd) I streak towards the goal line. Maggie's pace quickens. MAGGIE (cont'd) And I land on the goal line.
Bob beams to see Maggie's eager arrival at Ike's side.  H switches off the music and proceeds like a proud coach to pastor.

Okay, I'm the pastor.  Dearly beloved, blah, blah, blah.  So on and so forth. Ra ta ta ta.  Yabada dabada.  I now pronounce you man and wife.  Kiss the bride, badum dum. (then moving toward Ted) We have the crescendo that leads to us right back down the aisle and out the... Ike kisses Maggie.  It is a world class, Olympic kiss.  I kiss that changes everything and can never be taken back. a kiss you only get once in your life.

Bob's smile dies.  Cindy's mouth drops open as the kiss g and on.  Peggy loses control and screams. BOB (cont'd) Maggie!!!!? Like a bucket of water thrown on two dogs, Ike and Maggie startled out of their kiss.  They pull apart and smile at other. ANGLE ON:  Bob. BOB (cont'd) (furious) If you were imagining me, you did great. (to Ike) What the hell were you doing?
(eyes on Maggie) I'm sorry, Bob.  She kissed me back.
(dazed but happy) I kissed him back.
Yeah, I caught that.  Want to tell me how long this has been going on? Maggie looks at Ike, wondrous, confused.
About a minute...?
A little longer for me.
Really?
What do you expect me to say to this?
How about -- "I hope you'll be very happy together"? Bob hauls back and punches Ike in the face.  Ike drops.
I hope you'll be very happy together. Bob storms down the aisle and out of the church.
(to Peggy) Take care of him. Maggie leaves.
Bob is halfway down the walk.  Maggie appears at the chur and calls after him.

Bob, I'm sorry! (half to herself) At least I backed out before the wedding.  That's progress! He keeps marching.  Now Peggy appears next to Maggie.  Ma calls again. MAGGIE (cont'd) Some woman is going to make you a lot happier than I ever could... The words are barely out of her mouth when Cindy comes ou door, racing after Bob at a full sprint. MAGGIE (cont'd) See?

Well, Maggie -- in the words of Mrs. Pressman: "Holy moly".  Call me later. Peggy goes to her car.  Cindy joins her as Bob speeds off car.  Now Ike takes Peggy's place next to Maggie.  Maggie to face Ike.  They are both beet red, stammering and unab look at each other, trying to act normal.
Okay.  So... what, uh... What just happened?  Just now?  Jus then?  In there?
I don't know.  I, uh -- I frankly don't even want to talk about it.
Me, either. Ike GRABS Maggie and BOOM -- they are all over each other kissing frantically, tongues, hands, hair, elbow, you nam Blathering fools.
(blathering) I love you.  I love you.
(blathering) I love you, too. They come up for air.

Wait.  We have to talk.  We have to do some talking now.  Pull up a railing. Maggie sits on the railing, then Ike backs up and sits on opposite railing. IKE (cont'd) You have to go down an aisle and say "I do".  You have to get married.
To who?  Are you asking me?
Me? Ike backs up to opposite railing and sits facing Maggie.
Yes, you!
(thinks) Well, you do have the dress.
And the church.
And the wedding date.  There's the two of us. (beat) So, you think... maybe... You have to go down the aisle with somebody you love and who love you back.
I'm okay with that.
So am I.
So, we'll... They both nod and sit there smiling, sort of. The organis closes the church door.
Good night. Ike pulls his tape recorder out of his pocket and quietly into it.
I'm getting married.
They smile at each other and remain sitting.  Then, silen
Ike drives up and parks in front of the hotel as he talks cell phone.
Ellie's on the phone.  Fisher sits nearby.
Ike's going to get married. Fisher throws himself onto the carpet and rolls himself helpless with laughter. ELLIE (cont'd) (without turning to him) Fisher, if you pee on that Persian, I'll kill you.
Maggie talks to Peggy, Cindy and Grandma Julia.  Grandma sits under a hair dryer.  Sprout, the dog, sits in his ba
I love his eyes.  I just believe they're listening to you.
His hair... any color.
I like his tight butt. Peggy laughs.
Grandma!
(to Cindy) See, this is a mature relationship. She's really found it.
Ike and Maggie fishing.
They play ping-pong.  They laugh, enjoying the moment.
Ike and Maggie have fun playing cards.  The game is slapj
Maggie and Ike horseback riding.  They sit on their horse amongst trees, "nuzzling".  Ike reads as he pushes Maggie tire swing.
Ike and Maggie open and close a Hoberman ball by holding opposite ends in their teeth.  Grandma looks in.
There is a fire in the fireplace.  Maggie and Ike sit as shows Maggie some passages from his favorite books.  He's reading something from Yeats at the moment.  They seem ha

It is a media circus including FOUR REPORTERS, Midday wit Meredith and the T-shirt Vendor.  Plus three other people reporters are interviewing, a GERMAN LADY, BUTCH KENAN, a farmer and Grandma Julia.  Reporter DINA NAPOLI walks dow church steps.

Wedding bells are ringing for the fourth time today in Hale, Maryland. Maggie Carpenter, "Always a Bride -- Never a Bridesmaid", will be attempting to complete her fourth wedding ceremony. We'll come back on the air when the results are in.  Back to you, Jessica. Meredith, the low-end public access TV reporter, films hi pointing a cheap video camera himself.

The turnout for this morning's wedding is usually reserved for royalty or Hollywood stars, but Maggie Carpenter is Hale, Maryland's special star and the citizens of Hale are out in full force today. The NY T-shirt Vendor pitches his wares.

I got "Bye-bye Birdie".  "What part of 'I do' don't you understand?"... Get your "Runaway Bride" T-shirts here... Reporter JULIE MURPHY stands near Grandma Julia and Mrs. Pressman. JULIE MURPHY (Channel 6) The bride's been here for almost an hour, but being around in the beginning was never her problem.  We'll be here, showing you the full wedding ceremony, we hope. Reporter JACKI and TIFFANY stand at the edge of the CROWD reporting.

Will she or won't she?  That is on the minds of these several hundreds folks, who are standing here this morning. Not to mention on the mind of Groom Number #4, ex-USA Today columnist, Ike Graham, who is missing in action.

location: WINDOW OF CHURCH/INT. SUNDAY SCHOOL ROOM

text: INSERT window of church.  Peggy peers out the window at t carnival scene.  Cindy sits with Maggie as she leans forw doubled over on a child's chair.  Peggy moves from the wi sit with them.
(moves to window) He's not coming.  Watch.  He's not coming.
No, no.  I saw eight geese flying in a "V".
You and your lucky geese.  You always see geese.
Not eight...
And in a "V".
Eight is good... "V" could be Victory. They ad lib various words starting with the letter "V". is nervous.
Rub your ears.
Yes, rubbing your ears is very soothing. Cory does that to me when I hyperventilate. Maggie rubs her ears.
We do it to our dog.
It's hurting.
We'll rub. After they rub Maggie's ears a bit:
He's here!  He's here! They all squeeze and peer out window.  They scream in exc Cindy rushes to Maggie's wedding dress.
I'll get the dress.
He's here!... He's here!

Now's the time for calm... If you don't calm down, you won't get your dress on... (reassuringly) He's the one... He's the one. Peggy moves to help Cindy with the dress.  Maggie stands the window a moment.  She picks up a toy horse.
This is not a good sign. Maggie goes over to Peggy and Cindy, and starts to get in bridal gown.  They continue to ad lib words standing with letter "V".
We have to hurry.  The Sunday School kids will be here soon.
Ike pulls up slowly.  GUESTS peer through the his car win wave.  Ike rubs his headache.
Well, the groom just pulled up.  There was talk of a "now show", but he is here.
Ike Graham is here!

He moves as he takes it all in:  a FAMILY eats a fast foo on a neighbor's lawn, invited GUESTS flock by in their pa best, and local NEWS TEAMS block the way.  The STATE SENA making a speech welcoming the press to Maryland.  A large of reporters head up the church's stairs, hauling their equipment.  They enter the flood of PEOPLE streaming insi church.  Ike snaps.

Ike stops the car where it is and jumps out, slamming the anger.  The REPORTERS swarm around him as he gets out of They continue to pound him with questions as he walks to steps.  An OLDER LADY smacks him on the shoulder with a newspaper.  He turns in astonishment and continues up the steps.  He charges up the stairs and grabs Lee.
Shoot ours so she has one with an ending. Mrs. Pressman stands, shooting Ike with her video camera. IKE (cont'd) (pleading) Mrs. Pressman, please.
It's okay.  There's no microphone. You're no fun.
No, I'm not. Ike retreats into the church.  Lee comes up to him again video camera:  CHUFFA about Scorsese.

As Fisher and Ellie sign the guest book, a LOCAL LADY sta Ellie.  Ellie stares back at her until she leaves.  Ike w away from Lee and turns smack into Ellie and Fisher.  Ike his arms around them and gives them a big hug.
Friends.  Thank you.  Thank you. Over Ellie's shoulder, Ike sees Fisher's grinning face. IKE (cont'd) We are friends, aren't we, Fisher?
(grinning) Of course we are.  Of course.
Then you'll be my best man.
Well, I'm good, I don't know if I'm best.
Go talk to the pastor and he'll tell you what to do.  And someone will tell me what to do.

You always looked great in that suit... And Ike? (emotional) I'm happy for you, honey. Ellie whispers in his ear. ELLIE (cont'd) I'll have a car around the back to whisk you out of here if she runs. Ellie kisses him on the cheek and walks away.
Bob comes up to Ike.  He looks like he's going to punch I abruptly holds out a rose boutonniere.
You look awful.
(sarcastically) Thank you. Bob hands the flower to Ike.  Ike is shaking.  Bob catche and looks up to Ike.  It is a moment of clean honesty bet men.
Ike.  Need help? He takes the boutonniere and puts it on Ike's lapel. BOB (cont'd) I'm glad it's you.
Really?
I didn't want to find out I wasn't for her in the fourth quarter.
Got any last minute advice?
(motioning to their eyes) Maintain eye contact. Bob turns and leaves, going down a side staircase.
(to himself) Eye contact.  Eye contact. Out of the corner of his eye, Ike sees a pictures of Chri wall.  He leans into the picture and whispers. IKE (cont'd) Cover me. He walks into the chapel.
Ike steps up and stands next to Fisher.
(to Ike) I have no idea what I'm doing.
Your job is... the ring. (to Fisher) Do you have the ring?!

I just found out I'm best man!  I'm lucky I have a suit... What's wrong? Ike gives the ring to Fisher.  The Pastor approaches Ike. turns away and look out over the guests. IKE'SPOV:  There are most of the TOWNSPEOPLE we've come t know, plus some NEW YORKERS for Ike, with little ponytail Armani wire rims, Donna Karan bodysuits.  There's a lot o smirking, checking out the hicks, forming their stories f cocktail hour.  Elaine is in back all dressed in black, m Ike.  Mrs. Trout approaches Ike.
You should thank Lou and I for the wedding car -- a '63 Buick.
Thank you.
Oh, come on.  You're practically family. Mrs. Trout starts picking lint off Fisher's jacket.
Hello.  I'm Fisher.
This doesn't want to come out.
You just pull a hair from my neck.
Mrs. Trout, go back to your seat!
Peggy joins Maggie, who is blowing bubblegum and swaying front of an oscillating fan.  Grandma and Walter come in. Grandma gives her a kiss on the cheek.
Good luck, Maggie.
Thank you, Grandma. Grandma leaves.  Walter steps up.
(quietly to Maggie) I'm really rooting for this one.
Thank you, Dad. Peggy turns off the fan.  Cindy takes the bag from Maggie
Spit. Maggie spits her bubblegum into the bag.  Peggy hands Mag bouquet.
Let's go.
No sauntering down the aisle.  Just make time.  Let's just get there. Cindy and Peggy nod and leave.  The door closes.
Both extends his hand to Elaine.
Hi, I'm Elaine from New York.
Hello.  I'm Bob, Maggie's fourth attempt.
I'm sorry.
That's okay.  There's a lid for every pot.  Besides, I'm comfortable with Ike. I mean, Jack Dempsey lost his heavyweight title to a New Yorker.
I know.  Gene Tunney. The organ begins to play.  The organist is Ted.  Grandma, Mrs. Pressman and the Trouts watch.  Mrs. Trout picks lin her husband's jacket.
Cindy and Peggy enter with the confident air of people wh done this before.  They make it to the head of the aisle quickly.  Peggy gives Ike a wink and an encouraging smile
The door opens and Dennis sticks his head in.
They're ready, Maggie.

Just a second. Dennis closes the door behind him as he goes back into th chapel.  Maggie has a moment alone.  She looks at back do possible escape route, then changes her mind.  She signal start of the wedding by knocking on the door.
Immediately, Cory and Dennis open the doors for her entra All the guests stand as Maggie enter the chapel smiling.
The aisle stretches before her into infinity.  Faces gogg her from every direction.  The tiny figure of Ike stands beacon a long way off.
She plunges forward with a sped-up hesitation step.

Ike rocks imperceptibly, urging her on.  Peggy and Cindy little "come on" motions.  It seems to be working.  Maggi approaches rapidly.  The CROWD has turned from skepticism looks and noises of encouragement.
But then her feet gradually begin to slow.
Fisher gives a little "darn, so close" look.
But Ike is too busy maintaining eye contact.  His eyes ur Maggie closer -- loving her, willing her on.
Maggie stops her walk, gives Ike a teasing smile, and the resumes with her walk toward him.  His face.  Her face. face.  Her face.
Her foot inches forward.  The other follows.
A sigh now rises from the GUESTS as Maggie closes in on I smiles at her.  She smiles at him.  She is almost there.. there, smiling at Ike.  The Pastor gestures to the guests down.  They do.
Ike sneezes.  She looks down and imagines she sees the ca splitting apart.  And she bolts like a bat out of hell! flurry of white, she is halfway down the aisle before Ike what hits him.
Ike stands there dazed.  For a second.  Then she springs action, charging after her.

(yelling out) Block the doors! Like a general, he points to Dennis and Cory in the back sends them into action.  The doors shut in Maggie's face. she's a wild animal cornered.   She moves to the side.  T TOWNSPEOPLE stand so Ike can hurry through the pew.  Ike on the pews towards her as GUEST crowd the aisle, blockin path.  Like a gazelle, she leaps to the side aisle and sc down and away.  Fisher gets on his cell phone.  Ike charg one of the full pews, crosses the aisle and leaps across near the staircase to cut her off.  He grabs her veil and comes off in his hands.  Maggie disappears down the steps church basement.  Ike fumble with the veil and jumps over railing, landing on Dennis' toe.  He follows down the sta after her.  Mrs. Pressman and Walter exchange bet money.
Maggie comes down steps and enters the church children's school class.  A lot of KIDS And TEACHERS are doing relig arts and crafts.  As Maggie runs through:
There's a man coming down those steps with lots of candy in his pockets.  If you tickle him, he'll give candy. She gives her bouquet to a little GIRL as she goes by.  I down stairs.
Maggie! The KIDS mob him, grabbing his pockets.  Ike fights his w through KIDS.
Maggie as she's in the church kitchen and hops on counter heads out the window.  The window is wide enough.
Ike as he gets to the window, but Maggie is out in drivew
Maggie flies toward a FedEx truck at next house just leav
She gathers her dress and jumps in as Ike yells from wind then, quickly climbs out onto the lawn as the truck start pull away.

Maggie! Maggie looks back once, tearful and regretful, and disapp inside the truck.  The truck races off. The PHOTOGRAPHERS turn their cameras on Ike, en masse.  H enveloped by a barrage of bright lights. Ellie and Fisher, who have also stepped outside on chapel steps, are looking around as Ike turns around the corner past the church.
Look, he's running after her.
Look, he's in pretty good shape.
Poor Ike. They look after the FedEx truck and watch Ike chasing the down the road away from the church.
(running; yells) Maggie!
Where do you think she's going?
Wherever it is, she'll be there by ten- thirty tomorrow. Cindy, Cory, Peggy and Meredith also rush out of the chur comment on Maggie's runaway.  Further down the road, Ike chases the truck, yelling:

Maggie! As the truck rounds the bend in the road and disappears, stops and stares alone after the disappearing truck.  A s REPORTERS catch up to him, flashing pictures and asking questions.  Another camera flashes and we cut to:
Of Ike's stunned face on the cover of the USA Today.  The reads: "Hit and Run:  Runaway Bride Strikes again".  And headlines in other papers.
Kevin, the bartender, reads Jay's column, in the USA Toda entitled "Maggie's Mad Dash".
Various newspaper WORKERS also read Jay's column in the U Today entitled "Maggie Mad Dash" and "Hardware Honey Goes and Bolts" in another newspaper.
It's a night like any other in Hale -- the regular order things has been restored on its quaint streets.  Quartet in front of the hotel.  LEE AND CORY CHUFFA:  About where is.
Maggie is sitting, end of a long day.  Peggy sticks her h entrance door.
You okay?  I'm closing.
I'm just finishing up, too.
Want to go to Butch's for a drink or something?
(interrupting) No, I'm just going to head home.

Okay. Peggy starts to go, then moves close to Maggie. PEGGY (cont'd) (stepping closer and making a "V" with her fingers) You know, I was just thinking about that geese thing.  I think the "V" was half of a "W".  A "W" for...
What are you talking about?
Wedding.  Wedding. (holding Maggie's face) You just have to get the rest of your ducks in a row.
Thank you.  You still think that he was....
Quick.  Very quick. Peggy exits.  Maggie stares, losing herself in thought. VOICE startles her.
(whispers) Marry me, Maggie. Maggie jumps and turns to see:  DENNIS -- the kid from th school football team, popping up from a low position near counter.
(softly) Hi, Dennis.
